Award.AbstractNarration:
1619785-Ye

NSF has made an award in support of student registration fees, keynote speaker travel and publication expenses associated with the 42nd Annual Northeast Bioengineering Conference (NEBEC) being held at SUNY at Binghamton, Vestal, NY, April 5-7, 2016. The goal of NEBEC is to stimulate collaborations and to promote bioengineering research and education programs in the Northeast. The objectives of the meeting are to 1) To identify new collaboration opportunities, 2) To develop a community to share ideas, resources, and technologies, 3) To expose students to exciting research at the cutting edge of biomedical engineering, 4) To encourage students to pursue careers in biomedical engineering, 5), To introduce students to research leaders and encourage interactions, and 6) To stimulate new interactions between research groups in the Northeast. The theme of the meeting is "Biomedical Frontiers for the 21st Century." Topics to be addressed include: 3D bioprinting, cell manufacturing, nanomedicine and scalable nanobiomanufacturing, human brain mapping, neuron science and engineering, stem cells & regenerative medicine, biomaterials, bio-MEMS, organ-on-a-Chip, biomedical devices, biomechanics, systems biology & synthetic biology, tissue engineering and computational biology. These topics are covered in 3 Platform Sessions: 1) Regenerative Medicine and Advanced Biomanufacturing; 2) Tissue Engineering, Bioimaging and Engineering Biology; 3) Nanomedicine, Biomechanics, and Neuroscience/technology. A fourth session is designed for student attendees: Career Development in Biomedical Engineering & Biotechnology. At least 400 attendees from 28 area universities and approximately 20 respected keynote and plenary speakers will participate in the conference. Workshops will focus on industry participation and public advocacy needed to help translate basic biomedical research into clinical treatments. The goals of the conference, including the emphasis on student participation and career development, are well matched to programs supported by the Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental and Transport Systems (CBET) Division.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of the NEBEC is to stimulate collaborations and to promote biomedical engineering research and education programs in the Northeast. The rapid growth of biomedical industries and biomedical education programs in Northeast offers new opportunities to spur research, education, industry growth and innovation in biomedical science and engineering. The conference was held at the Binghamton University, SUNY April 5th-7th, 2016. The two and half day conference consisted of an Undergraduate Design Competition, a Graduate Research Poster Competition, a Biomedical & Biotechnology Career Fair, keynote and plenary speech sessions, and research oral/poster presentation sessions as well as panel discussions on emerging biomedical technologies. The conference session tracks included "Career Development in Biomedical Engineering and Biotechnology," "Regenerative Medicine & Stem Cell Engineering," "Biomaterials and Cancer Engineering," "Bio-MEMS and Biomedical Devices," "Biomedical Imaging, Tissue Engineering and 3D Bioprinting," "Synthetic and Systems Biology," "Nanomedicines," "Biofilm, and Pharmacology," "Biomechanics," and "Neuroscience/technology", and "Cognitive Science." The conference successfully attracted 450 attendees, including 361 students, 3 postdoctoral fellows, 61 faculty, and 25 industry investigators from 37 universities and companies in 10 northeast states. There were 195 undergraduate students from 12 universities in the Northeast submitted design projects for the Undergraduate Design Competition and 192 poster presentations selected from abstract submission. Three graduate students won the first, second and third awards through the Graduate Student Research Poster Award. There seven plenary speakers, three career keynote speakers, thirteen invited speakers, and 6 industry panelists delivered speeches at the conference. There were 30 podium research presentations selected from abstract submission. Most of these presenters were graduate students and postdoctoral fellows. There were 12 networking tables and career connection tables were set up in the conference. The industry sponsors included GE, Thermal Fisher Scientific, Noraxon, and Binghamton University Small Business Development Center. The conference brought together leaders in the field to inform and inspire students and faculty about progresses and research opportunities in biomedical science and engineering.
